channel.title: Digg Top Stories
channel.description: Digg - What the Internet is talking about right now

item.title: This Grisly Image Helped A Father Find His Son
item.description: Jeff Bauman is the man in the photograph that has become an icon of the Boston Marathon attack. If the world could not identify him immediately, Mr. Bauman’s father certainly could.

item.title: Boston Bomb Parts Pictured In Leaked FBI Bulletin
item.description: An intelligence bulletin issued to law enforcement includes a picture of a mangled pressure cooker and a torn black bag that the FBI says were part of a bomb that exploded during the Boston marathon.

item.title: American Exceptionalism Explained In One Map
item.description: Even after the tragedy in Boston, our country remains uniquely secure from foreign threats -- and that shapes how Americans see the world.

item.title: Why Doctors Can't Give You LSD (But Maybe They Should)
item.description: For the first time since the 1970s, researchers are being allowed to study the potential medical properties of the most tightly controlled substances around. But it's not easy.

item.title: How Long Does It Take Terrorist Groups To Claim Responsibility For An Attack?
item.description: One reason many are speculating that the Boston Marathon bombing was the work of a "home-grown" or "lone-wolf" terrorist is the absence of a foreign terrorist group claiming responsibility for yesterday's tragedy. But how long does it typically take foreign terrorists to own up to plots on American soil?

item.title: Finally, There's A Robot That Cleans When You Scream At It
item.description: LG's new Roboking wants to apply for a job as your cleaning minion, and it's happy to be bossed around.

item.title: Barbie Isn't Exactly A Picture Of Health
item.description: Contrary to what her shining hair, clear skin, and bright eyes might suggest, Barbie is basically dying. Or, rather, she was never alive in the first place.

item.title: Photos Of Giant Billboard People Looming Over Pedestrians
item.description: When Israeli photographer Natan Dvir visited New York City in 2008, he was taken aback by the massive advertising billboards dominating commercial hubs and the fact that giant models on them loomed over the pedestrians walking by.

item.title: How Can We Find And Defend Against Explosives?
item.description: New technology ranges from handheld bomb detectors to impromptu blast walls.

item.title: This Is Cuba's Digital Enemy Number One
item.description: Check out our video to learn about Cuba's underground railroad of USB drives, how to blog without a computer, and how Raúl Castro is getting craftier at using the Internet as a weapon against dissidents.

item.title: Scientists Fret As One Dying Language Disappears Every 14 Days
item.description: As many as half of the world’s 7,000 languages are expected to be extinct by the end of this century.

item.title: On The Road... Too Much?
item.description: Can John Kerry travel all the time and still be a great secretary of state?

item.title: If I Made Another Monkey Island...
item.description: Before I get into this fanciful post, I want to make one thing perfectly clear... actually, I'm just going to make it my first point. It's probably the most important one.

item.title: What Clues Do Explosions Leave Behind?
item.description: Incredibly useful ones.

item.title: The Computer Program That Has Learned To Beat Classic NES Games
item.description: Computer science researcher Tom Murphy built an AI program that will play "Super Mario" and other Nintendo Entertainment System games on its own.

item.title: The 10 Busiest Airline Routes By Passenger Volume
item.description: Research from travel-tech company Amadeus shows that 300 “super routes” were responsible for more than 20% of global airline traffic in 2012.

item.title: How Much Booty Do People Want?
item.description: Sex is like money: The more you think the Joneses have, the worse you feel.

item.title: Why Chess Should Be Required in U.S. Schools
item.description: It’s a game that motivates us to win, but also teaches us how to deal with defeat.

item.title: Here's What's Inside Google Glass' Box
item.description: Google Glass has arrived in the hands of early users. Here's what it looks like coming out of the very pretty packaging.

item.title: Silk Road Founder Says Bitcoin Booms And Busts Won't Kill His Black Market
item.description: As the crypto-currency Bitcoin has skyrocketed in value over the last weeks and then fallen even faster, it’s produced plenty of excitement and heartache for investors.

item.title: Gambling Ring Catering To Wall Street, Celebrities And Athletes Busted
item.description: A scion of one of the world’s most influential and wealthiest art-dealing families was charged on Tuesday with playing a leading role in a gambling and money laundering scheme that was carried out under the direction of a Russian organized crime group and included high-stakes poker games involving Wall Street financiers, Hollywood celebrities and professional athletes.

item.title: The Earliest Stop Motion Animations Are Weirdly Wonderful
item.description: These century-old stop motion films are far more wonderful than they are weird. And they're pretty weird.
